marker.label: Annie Falconer
marker.comment: 95 ft

marker.label: Caution!
marker.comment: Watch your depth! Don't try to cut this corner at speed. VERY shallow.

marker.label: Big Sandy Bay
marker.comment: The best white sand beach in the whole region

marker.label: Big Sandy Bay
marker.comment: The best white sand beach in the whole region. Relatively secluded too, and guaranteed mostly deserted in moderate Westerly or Southerly breezes.

marker.label: Tucked in under Horseshoe Island
marker.comment: Sheltered behind Horseshoe Island is a good spot. Very shallow, rocky bottom, still good if the wind shifts to almost any other direction.

marker.label: Aloha
marker.comment: 55 ft

marker.label: Under Simcoe Island
marker.comment: Very well protected, can go close to shore, but it's a sandy bottom.

marker.label: General Wolfe
marker.comment: Not really a marina, more a town dock where you can park for a short period (make sure you let the bartender know) to explore around Marysville for a while.

marker.label: Everitt Point Park
marker.comment: Beautiful waterfront park with a georgeous flat-rock surface that, depending on water levels, you can venture out and sit upon, surrounded by crashing water in a breeze.

marker.label: Wolfe Island Ferry
marker.comment: Free for pedestrians.

marker.label: Lake Ontario Park
marker.comment: A huge park with great waterfront views. Note that camping and carnaval rides are no longer offered at Lake Ontario Park.

marker.label: P.O.H. Launch Ramp
marker.comment: Excellent wide and steep concrete ramp. Suitable for virtually any tow vehicle and any boat. POH has the best ramps in the area.

marker.label: P.O.H. Launch Ramp
marker.comment: Excellent wide and steep concrete ramp. Suitable for virtually any tow vehicle and any boat. These are the best launch facilities in the area.

marker.label: Portsmouth Olympic Harbour Park
marker.comment: Not really directly on the water, but close enough

marker.label: MacDonald Memorial Park
marker.comment: This is where many of Kingstons best windsurfers launch thair boards on windy days.

marker.label: Kingston Yacht Club
marker.comment: The wooden 'T' dock is suitable for launching small boats on dollies. The 'T' dock is pulled out for the winter so it's not available between late fall and early spring

marker.label: Kingston Yacht Club
marker.comment: This is a private yacht club offering reciprocal priviledges but with limited visitor docking. They sell fuel.

marker.label: Kingston Yacht Club
marker.comment: The marine railway slip (cement launch) is suitable for small boats on dollies or on hand-moveable trailers. There's a wooden dock alongside the ramp which is handy. Often effectively blocked in early spring and in fall by boats on land for winter storage.

marker.label: Foot of West Street
marker.comment: Cement launch. Good manoevering space.

marker.label: Ontario Park
marker.comment: A narrow grassy waterfront park just East of the West Street launch ramp.

marker.label: Marine Museum of the Great Lakes
RMC Campus
marker.comment: The Royal Military College makes accessible the whole of its 2 linear kilometers of waterfront, and provides many classic views of Kingston and Fort Henry.

marker.label: Confederation Basin
marker.comment: Not really a marina, more a town dock where you can park a short while for free and overnight for a fee.

marker.label: Confedration Park
marker.comment: This park is across from Kingston City Hall.

marker.label: Fort Henry
marker.comment: Fort Henry is 19th century British military fortress and is both a museum and a spectacular historic site. Its grounds stretch to the water though it's not exactly a people-friendly waterside. For example, there is are paths or walkways near the water, and you'll need to ascend the big hill just to cross the moat that runs from the fort down to the water.

marker.label: Fort Henry
marker.comment: Fort Henry is 19th century British military fortress and is both a museum and a spectacular historic site. Its grounds stretch to the water though it's not exactly a people-friendly waterside. For example, there is are paths or walkways near the water, and you'll need to ascend the big hill just to cross the moat that runs from the fort down to the water.

marker.label: CFB Kingston Yacht Club
marker.comment: This is a private yacht club with no public facilities.

marker.label: Arrowhead Beach Park
marker.comment: Narrow sand beach attached to a park with play structures. The bottom can be weedy. Perfect for an outing with little kids.

marker.label: Arrowhead Beach Park
marker.comment: Narrow sand beach attached to a park with play structures. The bottom can be weedy. Perfect for an outing with little kids.

marker.label: MetalCraft Marine
marker.comment: Metalcraft Marine are builders of aluminum high-speed fire and rescue boats sold worldwide.

marker.label: Kingston Marina
marker.comment: A full service marina with the largest crane in the region.

marker.label: Inner Harbour
marker.comment: Kingston's inner harbour is an ideal anchorage but you'll need a bridge lift to get there.

marker.label: Rotary Park
marker.comment: Rotary Park is found at the end of Coverdale Ave and ...

marker.label: Doug Fluhrer Park
marker.comment: Google Maps is wrong: the railroad tracks in this park are long gone. A nice waterside park that's been shamelessly neglected by the City of Kingston for many years.

marker.label: Government Warf on Collins Bay
marker.comment: Cement launch, cement pier. Not a lot of room to turn around for larger boats. It is best to back larger boats in from the road.

marker.label: Deep in Collins Bay
marker.comment: Deep into Collins Bay is okay in a SW breeze, the further in the better. Shallow, muddy bottom. If things get bleak, dock at one of the marinas at the apex of the bay.

marker.label: Sibbit Park
marker.comment: Google Maps doesn't get the shoreline quite right out here.

marker.label: Orchard Park
marker.comment: Cement launch. This is a narrow ramp that leads to shallow water, just noth of the Wollen Mill building

marker.label: Emma Martin Park
marker.comment: Google Maps gets the name of this one wrong.

marker.label: Riverside Park
marker.comment: Google Maps doesn't get the shoreline quite right out here. Riverside park is a nice quiet park off Faircrest Blvd with a gradual slope that's ideal for launching a canoe.

marker.label: Behind Milton Island
marker.comment: The lee of Milton Island offers some protection, especially if you can get into the bay that cuts into its East side.

marker.label: Bell Island
marker.comment: A nice wooded area surrounded by water. Sand beach at its North Eastern end, but swim here at your peril since there is a pollution-leaching landfill closeby.

marker.label: Bell Island Park
marker.comment: ... but swim here at your peril since there's a pollution leaching landfill very close by.

marker.label: Bell Park Fairways
marker.comment: A municipal 9-hole golf course with water views.

marker.label: 100 Ft Park
marker.comment: This narrow park follwos a ravine, between Limeridge St and Medley Court, down to the river, then stretches South along the river bank for a short distance.

marker.label: Rideau Marina
marker.comment: Cement launch. A nice wide ramp that's also served by a 25-ton travel lift.

marker.label: Rideau Marina
marker.comment: A full service marina with a 25 ton travel lift.

marker.label: Lilla Burke Park
marker.comment: Google Maps misplaces Rideau Marina on what is actually Lilla Burke Park, a nice waterside park with paths, picnic tables, and a play structure in a fine neighborhood. An easy slope leads to a rocky beach that is a good place to launch a canoe, kayak, rowing shell, or a small sailboat

marker.label: Maclean Park
marker.comment: Maclean Park starts behind the Pittsburgh Branch of the Kingston Public Library and paths stretch down to the waterfront where you'll find benches.

marker.label: Grass Creek Park
marker.comment: A big park in very pleasant surroundings, and an ideal spot for a swim or to lainch a small boat from its beach. This municipal park is an ideal picnic location, and it's located beside the MacLachlin Woodworking Museum.

marker.label: Kingston Mills Locks
marker.comment: A nice park that borders both Colonel By Lake and the Northern stretch of the Great Cataraqui River below the locks. This is a great picnic spot, as well as a moderate to advanced rock-climing spot.

marker.label: MacLachlan Woodworking Museum
marker.comment: Located right next to Grass Creek Park.

marker.label: Rideau Acres Campground
marker.comment: Good launch, steel grating over gravel. Accommodates boats up to 25 feet. Dock, parking and picnic tables available. Launch fee: $5
